text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Friday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Foreign Minister Toomas Ilves met NATO Secretary-General Javier Solana and European Commission's Hans van den Broek. The latter assures Ilves of Estonia's good reputation in the Commission.

- The Fatherland Union opposition party is concerned with concessions made to Russia by the government, which may lead to Estonia becoming Russia's satellite, parliament vice-chairman Tunne kelam said.
- Parliament rejected a draft law on granting the General Staff the right to investigate crimes committed in the armed forces.
- The wages of President Lennart Meri are lower than those of his colleagues in Latvia and Lithuania.
- Union Bank sold 44 percent of the shares of the shipping firm Hansatee back to the firm.
- The management of the gas firm Eesti Gaas decided to sell 24.11 percent of the shares at a public offer.
